hints.content:
This question is the same as asking, 

$\qquad\red{\dfrac34}$ of what quantity of chocolate milk is $\blue{\dfrac38}$ of a liter?

 We can write this symbolically as

$\qquad\red{\dfrac34} \times ? = \blue{\dfrac38}$

which is equivalent to the division problem $\blue{\dfrac38} \div \red{\dfrac34}$ .

$\quad\blue{\dfrac38} \div \red{\dfrac34}$   

$= \blue{\dfrac38} \times \green{\dfrac43}$ $\quad\text{rewrite dividing by} \red{\dfrac34}$ $\text{as multiplying by}$ $\green{\dfrac43}$  

$=\dfrac{\blue3 \times \green4}{\blue8 \times \green3}$ $\quad\text{multiply the numerators and denominators}$

$= \dfrac{12}{24}$ $\qquad\text{reduce this fraction to get the final answer}$
$ = \dfrac12$ of a liter of chocolate milk

question.content:
Ana drank $\dfrac38$ of a liter of chocolate milk from a container, which was   $\dfrac34$ of the chocolate milk that was originally in the container.

**How much chocolate milk was originally in the container?**  

 [[☃ numeric-input 1]] liters

answers.message: Be careful, there was less than 1 liter originally in the container.

hints.content:
The whole quantity of chicken is $\dfrac78$ $\text{ kg}$. The groups are the bags, and each group contains $\blue{\dfrac14}$ $\blue{\text{ kg}}$ of chicken. We want to know how many groups of $\blue{\dfrac14}$ $\blue{\text{ kg}}$ it will take to get the whole quantity of $\dfrac78$ $\text{ kg}$.

We can write this symbolically as:

$\green{\text{(number of groups)}} \times \blue{\text{(amount in each group)}} = \text{whole quantity}$

$\green{\text{?}} \times \blue{\dfrac14} = \dfrac78$

This is equivalent to the division problem $\dfrac78 \div \blue{\dfrac14}$ .

$\quad\dfrac78 \div \blue{\dfrac14}$ 

$= \dfrac78 \times \green{\dfrac41}$   $\quad\text{Rewrite dividing by} \blue{\dfrac14}$ $\text{as multiplying by}$ $\green{\dfrac41}$
$=\dfrac{7 \times \green4}{8 \times \green1}$
Since $3\frac12$ bags will hold the  $\dfrac78 \text{ kg}$ of chicken, Andrei will need a minimum of 4 bags to bag the chicken.

question.content:
Andrei bought $\dfrac78$ $\text{ kg}$ of chicken. He is going to put the chicken in bags that each hold $\dfrac14$ $\text{ kg}$ when full.

**What is the minimum number of bags Andrei will need to bag the chicken?**

[[☃ numeric-input 1]] bags

answers.message: Be careful, 3 bags will not fit all of the chicken.

hints.content:
Let's sort the data points from least to greatest.

$\qquad 22,29,34,36,39,41$

Since there is an even number of data points, the median will be halfway between the middle two data points. [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\qquad 22,29,\purple{\large34\text{ | }}\purple{\large36},39,41$

options.explanation: Notice that there are $3$ data points below the median and $3$ data points above the median.

hints.content:
The median is the mean of the two middle numbers. [[☃ explanation 1]]

$\qquad \dfrac{\purple{34} + \purple{36}}{2} =\dfrac{70}{2}= 35$ apples

options.explanation: Finding the mean of $34$ and $36$ gives us the number that is halfway between them.

hints.content: The median is $35$ apples.

question.content:
Kim is planning her family and really wants to have a baby girl. She plans to keep having babies until she gets a girl, and then stop having new babies.

Kim also doesn't want to have too many children, so she designs a simulation to estimate the probability that it takes $4$ or more total babies to get a girl. For the simulation, Kim uses a random number generator to create single digit numbers.

* Odd digits $(1, 3, 5, 7, 9)$ represent a baby $\greenD{\text{boy}}$.
* Even digits $(0,2,4,6,8)$ represent a baby $\goldD{\text{girl}}$.

For each trial, Kim generates a sample of single digit numbers, one at a time, until she gets an even number which ends the trial. The table below shows the first $12$ trials of the simulation.

question.content:
In this article, we'll learn how to run and interpret simulations. Being able to run and interpret simulations is like a super power because it allows us to ask and answer interesting questions that would otherwise be really hard.

**For example, given that LeBron makes $70\%$ of his free throws, what is the probability that he makes $8$ or more out of his next $10$ free throws?**

This turns out to be a very hard probability to calculate, but that's where a simulation is like a superpower. We can estimate this probability using a simulation. 


For example, we could simulate LeBron shooting free throws by randomly selecting numbers from $1$ to $10$.  Since LeBron has a $70\%$ chance of making any individual free throw, we let $\greenD{\text{the numbers 1 to 7 represent a make}}$ and $\redD{\text{the numbers 8 to 10 represent a miss.}}$

Here is one sample:

>${5, 2, 7, 7, 9, 2, 1, 8, 3, 4}$

Each number represents LeBron shooting one free throw. The number $5$, for example, is a make because it is in the range $1$ to $7$. On the other hand, the number $9$ is a miss because it is in the range $8$ to $10$.

Let's color code the numbers in the sample to help us see which free throws are $\greenD{\text{makes}}$ and which are $\redD{\text{misses}}$:

>${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$

In this sample, we count that LeBron made $8$ out of $10$ free throws. But this sample alone isn't enough to estimate the probability of LeBron making $8$ out of $10$ free throws. To get a good estimate, we'd have to simulate using many samples. 

To understand how this works, let's go through the process with just $8$ samples. This won't give us a great estimate because it isn't many samples, but it will help us build our intuition.

(TO COMPLETE)

 | Sample |
:-: | :-: | 
$1$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$
$2$ | ${\redD{10}, \greenD4, \redD{9}, \greenD5, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$
$3$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$
$4$ | ${\redD{10}, \greenD4, \redD{9}, \greenD5, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$
$5$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$
$6$ | ${\redD{10}, \greenD4, \redD{9}, \greenD5, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$
$7$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$
$8$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$

For each sample, we want to know how many free throws LeBron made and if it was $8$ or more:

 | Sample | Free throws made | $8$ or more?
:-: | :-: | :-: | :-:
$1$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$ | $8$ | Yes
$2$ | ${\redD{10}, \greenD4, \redD{9}, \greenD5, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$|$6$| No
$3$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$ | $8$| Yes
$4$ | ${\redD{10}, \greenD4, \redD{9}, \greenD5, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$ | $6$| No
$5$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$ | $6$| No
$6$ | ${\redD{10}, \greenD4, \redD{9}, \greenD5, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$ | $6$| No
$7$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$ | $8$| Yes
$8$ | ${\greenD5, \greenD2, \greenD7, \greenD7, \redD9, \greenD2, \greenD1, \redD8, \greenD3, \greenD4}$ | $8$| Yes

LeBron made $8$ or more free throws in $4$ of the $8$ samples, so our estimate is that LeBron makes $8$ or more out of $10$ free throws $\dfrac{4}{8} = 50\%$ of the time.

Of course, this is just an estimate. If we did another simulation of $8$ samples we would probably get a different estimate. Estimates that come from simulations with more samples are generally more accurate. 

For example, an estimate from a simulation with $1000$ samples would be much more accurate than our estimate from just $8$ samples. Of course, $1000$ samples would be really tedious to do by hand, but luckily we have computer programs to help us run large simulations.
